Award.AwardTitle: VOSS: Building Shared Leadership to Strengthen Virtual Team Effectiveness

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The connection between shared or distributed leadership and virtual team effectiveness is growing more important as complex world issues increasingly require distributed collaboration. Organizational researchers lack an understanding of the causes and consequences of the distribution of influence across team members in distributed virtual teams. Taking a multidisciplinary approach, this research investigates shared leadership within the sociotechnical paradigm, integrating perspectives from shared leadership, empowerment, group process, and media choice theories. This research examines a set of antecedents and outcomes of shared leadership in virtual tams, combining a pair of controlled lab studies with a field study to look at generalizability of the principles learned from the lab studies. These three studies systematically examine the combined effects of communication medium, initiating mechanisms, group processes and structure on team effectiveness. The first study manipulates introductory meeting communication medium and the use of initiating mechanisms (such as goal clarification) to identify their impact on shared leadership among team members engaged in a sophisticated decision making simulation. This study traces the development of group processes and shared leadership over the course of the simulation and their impact on team knowledge sharing, performance, and viability. A second lab study evaluates the extent to which empowering (versus directive) leadership by an appointed leader enables shared leadership among virtual team members, particularly within the context of initiating mechanisms. A third field study assesses the influence of distributed expertise and extent of geographical dispersion on shared leadership patterns to evaluate the impact of shared leadership on team effectiveness among intact organizational virtual teams.

These findings will contribute to knowledge concerning how virtual team leadership, processes and structure interact with computer and communication support technology to affect team performance. Organizations are increasingly relying upon virtual teams and the results of this research will have a broad impact on the scientists, engineers, managers, members of the workforce, and students engaged in these activities. This project will provide evidence-based guidelines for organizing, managing, and working in virtual teams. It will enhance practitioners' understanding of the form(s) of leadership best suited for particular types of virtual teams and the corresponding processes and structures required for effective performance. Research results will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate curriculum and made available through alumni workshops. In addition, the project will contribute directly to the education of three graduate students and two undergraduate students by providing a high quality research experience. The results of this research can inform the policy makers and technical developers who shape collaborative infrastructure, incentives, and processes enabling more effective virtual teams and enhancing innovation and competitiveness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development and dispersion of advanced technology-mediated communication has enabled the rapid diffusion of distributed teams. Often called virtual teams, such teams are typically geographically and/or organizationally distributed. While virtual teams potentially offer significant advantages in terms of being able to draw on distributed expertise quickly and across geographical boundaries, such teams can also pose significant challenges. Due to their distributed and diverse nature, such teams can be prone to fragmentation and enhanced conflict, often leading to disappointing outcomes. Multiple scholars have pointed to a major need to better understand leadership practices that may help virtual teams achieve their promise as a vehicle for advanced discovery, learning, innovation and outcome effectiveness.

As a result, this research program evaluated the promising potential connection between shared or distributed leadership and virtual team effectiveness. Shared leadership is characterized by the distribution of influence across multiple team members. As such, shared leadership has the possibility of being effective in situations in which team members are dispersed and cannot easily meet collectively face-to-face. In investigating shared leadership, this research took a multidisciplinary approach by drawing on perspectives from shared leadership, empowerment, group process, and media technology theories to help assess the challenges of teamwork via a technology-mediated interface. Specifically, the research involved three studies, which included two separate sophisticated decision making simulations and a field study involving virtual teams in a major professional services organization.

Overall, the results are supportive of the value of distributed or shared leadership in virtual teams. Findings also demonstrated the usefulness of empowering (versus directive) leadership as a means of encouraging subsequent shared leadership in teams, which, in turn, ultimately led to higher performance. Moreover, the research pointed to an important role for virtual leaders in coaching teams during instances of unanticipated circumstances with which teams often must cope. Results also showed that leaders need to be particularly mindful of sustaining their own communication with all members of the team collectively despite team member dispersion. The notion that encouraging high amounts of explicit knowledge sharing is particularly important in virtual or distributed teams was also supported.

In the arena of intellectual merit, this program of research advances knowledge and understanding related to virtual teams in the following areas: shared leadership and virtual teams, relational mechanisms, team empowerment, virtual team processes, impact of virtuality in teams, virtual team effectiveness, and overall theory building with respect to virtual team shared leadership processes.

In the arena of broader impact, this program of research addresses major issues regarding leadership in virtual teams that are of strong interest to students in business and scientific disciplines, who will need to work in virtual teams; leaders/executive in organizations, who need to understand how best to organize and manage virtual teams; members of the working public, many of whom already work in such teams or will do so in the future.; and policy makers who can impact infrastructure, incentives, and other factors aimed at enabling more effective forms of virtual teams in behalf of enhanced innovation and competitiveness. Effective virtual teams also potentially allow for greater inclusion of underrepresented groups. Because this program of research directly addresses both the social and technology-mediated aspects of virtual teams, it directly adds to fundamental understanding of virtual organizations as sociotechnical systems by building and testing relevant theory.
